dialogues.text: That's all he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She arches her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we can't ask him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael driving an aged DeSoto through the blanketed stra fields of Center Valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father had bought the DeSoto fifteen years before.  Driving it reminded me of him.  Which I considered a neutral fact...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the wheel, using a cherry wood knob, specially m his convenience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it was pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following the curve, fields are pure white to the horizon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow made all the fields into one. The notion that one man might kill another for a small patch, made no sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead, a Willys station wagon has run into a ditch.  A aged Japanese man is working at a rear wheel with a shove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I knew such things occurred. Having been to war and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man is Hisao Imada, and we can now see his eldest dau working with a shovel behind the car.  Ishmael pulls up b them.  And gets out. He crunches over to where Hisao works...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I give you folks a lift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatsue has come around the car now, pulling her snowflake from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't look at her.  I thought that would be best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes on Ishmael's profile, Hatsue goes to her father' Murmurs to him in Japanese.  WHen he answers, she turns t Ishmael...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father is grateful for your kindness.  But he will free his car, shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael smiles softly.  This car isn't going anywhere.  H Hatsue, reaching gently for her shovel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael drives with Hisao beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's caused you trouble. But don't you think the snow is beautiful, coming down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes flick to Hatsue in the rearview mirror.  She sta the side window, concentrating on the world.  Two strands hair pasted against her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, her eyes SNAP to meet Ishmael's in the mirror. away.  Hers hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This trial is unfair.  You should write about that in your newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps driving.  And he keeps his eyes on the road. ISHMAEL (calmly) What should I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that.  This trial is wrong, they are calling a good man a killer. It is only about prejudice, and that is unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks.  As he drives.  Hisao Imada silent beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all expect the world to be fair. As if we have some right t...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean everyone.  Just people who can do things because they can arrest people or convict them.  Or run a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And his eyes come up.  Meet hers in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should write a column. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She studies his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smile.  On either side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think people.  Should be fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes on the road now.  The farmhouse seen through the screen of white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you write that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice is soft.  The difference is palpable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice is kindness and friendship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was part of her life again.  I was a person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tower of reinforced concrete, rising a hundred feet abo sea.  Ishmael's hand in his pocket.  Trudging toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael being led into a cramped room, stacked floor to c with wooden crates, file cabinets, duffel bags.  Our host LEVANT, a young Coast Guard radioman nearly six foot six, huge Adam's apple, and kinky black hair.  He gestures aro room at all the records.  Voila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the night watch?  On the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since September.  Last guys got transferred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael looks around.  There is a lot of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you keep the records, or contribute to 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shorthard the radio transmis- sions, write 'em up, file 'em in a cabinet.  Nobody ever looks. Just take up space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael nods.  Guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kinds of radio transmissions? Fisherman in trouble, and such.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Innocent question.  Random example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All kinds.  Make yourself at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And leaves.  Ishmael looks at the task before him.  Then, the window.  Dark now.  His reflection stares back.  As t as he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael at 24, carrying milk and crackers down the aisle grocery store, the empty sleeve of his mackinaw pinned up elbow.  He turns the corner to see... ...three people in line at the register.  The second is H infant carried at her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd been back two months.  It was the first time I'd seen her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He joins the line.  The CHECKER glances his way, then loo awkwardly down.  This makes the others turn.  And Hatsue' Meet his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice, the face, are cool and formal.  There is no an unkindness.  Only the absence of warmth.  Ishmael nods. hard, stricken.  His heart pounds in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't say anything.  I just stood there, hating her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about your arm.  Kabuo and I.  Are very sor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japs did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows where to look.  Down, away, anything.  But H never blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shot it off.  At Tarawa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds her ground, her eyes soften, somehow.  Somewher compassion and pity.  Her slender fingers stroke the baby shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry I said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the feeling comes to his eyes.  Everything he will ne her.  A murmur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about everything.  All of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops his milk and crackers on the counter. And walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael sits alone.  Beyond the glass, a SEARCHLIGHT swee sea, the snow-covered shore.  But Ishmael stares at a fol in his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: September 16.  At 1:42 A.M., the dead of night.  The S.S. West Corona, a Greek-owned freighter, was lost. In heavy fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His finger.  Traces a line of the report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They radioed to the lighthouse. They would have to dogleg, bisecting Ship Channel Bank.  And Seaman Philip Milholland wrote that down.  In his report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl Heine drowned.  In Ship Channel Bank.  And his watch stopped.  At 1:47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks out through the glass.  As if he could watch it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge freighter plowing through. Throwing a wake big enough to fling any man overboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ishmael removes the page from the file.  Slowly, he f into quarters.  Slides it into his coat pocket. ISHMAEL (calls out) Seaman...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And closes the file.  Slips it back into the cabinet.  Le appears, vaguely irritated by the summons.  So Ishmael sm Sorry, nothing important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you have this detail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Smoltz came on dogwatch September 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael's face.  Just to clarify...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, early morning the 16th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, night of the 16th, morning the 17th.  We replaced two guys named Miller and Milholland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Ishmael nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got transferred that day. Out to Cape Flattery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some seaman's loast report. Stuffed in a cabinet, good as lost forever.  No one knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael rises, stiffly.  Starts to pull on his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get what you come for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ishmael looks at the youngster.  A little oddly.  Adm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I'm not completely sure. What that was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael at 24, crouched among trees.  Above a sunlit stre beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left the grocery, and wrote a letter.  I apologizes from my heart. I should never have said that word to her.  I never would again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on his face.  Eyes gazing down.  At something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sat in my desk for two weeks. Before I threw it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sighs.  Rises slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew her car.  And sometimes when I'd see it, I'd...drive that way.  At a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See Hatsue down on the beach.  Alone, raking for steamer Her baby beside her on a blanket, beneath an umbrella. Ishmael walks down to the sand.  Crosses to where she wor squats down.  At a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must have seen who was coming.  Because the words do startle her.  Or slow her work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm married, Ishmael.  It isn't right for us to be alone.  People will t...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no one here, and I've got to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her back is to him.  She is motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you owe me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she turns.  Her eyes go first to her sleeping child. walks over, and sinks to the sand.  Just before him.  Nea to touch. She looks in his eyes.  And waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm like a dying person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words just came out.  His eyes move over her face.  H for her is naked, beyond his ability to cope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't sleep.  I tell myself this can't go on, but it goes on anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems at the edge of insanity.  Or tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did a terrible thing, Ishmael. I knew what you felt.  And what I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sadness in her voice.  But strength as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I never found the courage to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes swim with tears.  He chokes them back, he has to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll think this is crazy, but all I want is to hold you.  Just once. And smell your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She absorbs this.  No sign of repulsion or anger.  Her ey wise.  And very sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to hear this, I can never touch you, Ishmael.  Not once, not ever.  There's no half- way.  As much as I know it hurts you, you have to let this go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I want to forget you, I do. I think if you hold me, just this once, I can walk away and never speak to you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just keeps looking at him.  There is a bravery to her gaze.  Her calm resolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please?  As one human being to another, just because I'm miserable and don't know where to turn.  I need to be in your arms.  If it's just for thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pleading look holds her for a moment.  In the silence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hurt for you.  Whether you'll ever believe that or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feeling behind her eyes.  First time she lets it show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel sick sometimes, with the guilt of what I've done to you. And I can't make it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises slowly.  Brushes the sand from her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hold you would be wrong and deceitful.  You're going to have to live without holding me, that is the truth of the way things are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes one step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things end.  They do.  Get on with your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And turns away.  She gathers her baby in her arms.  Takes blanket, her umbrella, her rake and her pail.  He watches moving, as she gathers her things.  Gathers them as if he there.  And with her back turned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on with your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks slowly away.  Her baby cries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a steaming soup kettle, resting on a woodstove. hand stirs with a wooden ladle.  PULL BACK to see... HELEN CHAMBERS, slender and strong and keen.  She is not code of fairness and self-reliance is written on the fine features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drove from the lighthouse to my mother's place.  I brought her some groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the window, snow falls more heavily than ever.  Si Spellbinding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father thought that heavy snow was God's kindness.  Despite the hardship, it brought us beauty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael at the rustic table.  Watching her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and reminded us.  Of our place in things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Softer.  Not bitter, but regretful that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe in God anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agnostics don't believe or disbelieve, Ma.  We just don't pretend we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins ladling the soup into big porcelain bowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know God, we feel Him.  You felt Him as a child.  I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And turns.  Looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a long time ago.  What a child feels...that's different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She studies him silently for a moment.  Then brings the b the table...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spend the night, will you?  Don't go back out into all that snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sets them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt Milholland's report in my pocket.  And wondered why I wasn't telling her.  Telling someone. What I'd found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been busy with that trial, I suppose.  Such a travesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her seat.  As he watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only arrested that poor soul because he's Japanese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seattle boys think he's guilty.  They say the evidence is rock solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to eat.  Eyes on her bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not his neighbor, like you are.  He is a husband, a father, he risked his life for their country. The same as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't the facts that matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up.  Straight to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, folks are pretty cold. And folks who believe in nothing else...they're cold, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mistaking her meaning.  He swallows.  Uneasy as always path of her disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried to understand your unhappiness, all these years. Having gone to war, losing your arm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The directness of her gaze.  He can't turn from that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But other boys came back.  And pushed on.  They found girls, and married, had babies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't flinch.  His voice too quiet with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday I'll get lucky, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too quiet to conceal the hurt.  She thinks it is hurt she caused.  It changes her tone to a plea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father fought at Belleau Wood, it took him years to get over it.  Nightmares, tears, b...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but he found you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't the war, Ishmael.  All those years growing up.  You never had a real girl of your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now he looks down.  He sees that his fist is tight ar handle of his spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know you have it in you to love.  I know that much.  I wish I knew more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fingers open, and the spoon clatters softly on the wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stay tonight.  Thanks for asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael wanders through a silent room.  A bed, a dresser. table and lamp.  A room denuded of all decoration, all po all sign of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came back from the war to this room.  I stayed a few months.  Until my father passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael at 24, the left sleeve of his dark suit of mourni at the elbow.  The diggers are filling a grave in distanc Mourners mingle, some casting glances back at Ishmael.  K their distance out of awkwardness rationalized as respect One man comes to him.  MASATO NAGAISHI is aging and frail voice is clear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Japanese people of the island are saddened by this loss.  Your father was a man of great fairness and compassion for others...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands at a respectful distance.  Ishmael clears his t nods, thank you.  No words to say.  So the small man adds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend to us.  And to all people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.  They are a tableau of stone.  Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no more.  The man takes a step back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know you will follow in his footsteps.  And honor his legacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which changes Ishmael's face.  To something harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it then.  And often since. A balance, he's said.  Finding the facts.  That folks needed to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ishmael stands at an open closet.  Cardboard boxes have b aside.  One has been searched for treasure.  The page is hand.  Only slightly discolored by age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Ishmael.  These things are very difficult to say.  I can't think of anything more painful than writing this letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes his eyes. ISHMAEL (a murmur) Think of reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't love you, Ishmael.  There is no more honest way to say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries the letter to the twin bed.  Where he slept al Thinking of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever we were together, I knew it.  I loved you and I didn't love you at the same moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sinks slowly.  As if beneath the letter's weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last time.  At the cedar tree. I knew we could never be right together.  And that soon I would have to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are dry.  The letter has used up his tears long

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last time I will write to you.  I am not yours anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets the letter on the bed beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you the very best.  Your heart is large and you are gentle and kind.  I know you will do great things in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches now to his inside coat pocket.  Withdrawing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must say good-bye to you now. Our lives will move on.  The best we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a page.  Folded in quarters.  Sets it near the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milholland's report was like her letter.  Something no one else. Would ever read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at them.  Side by side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thing about having only one hand. It's hard to tear pages up.  And I wasn't carrying a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies back.  Across the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I thought of my father.  The man who would have taken this report to Judge Fielding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears stand in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But every reporter.  Chooses his own balance.  FInds the facts that matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuts the eyes.  Against them.  Against everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, the freighter was only a theory.  It proved nothing at all.  There were other facts. That mattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We CLOSE on his face.  The tightness of the muscles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow I would write a column. About prejudice.  And she would be grateful.  For my large...and gentle...heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes open, they are blank.  Staring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband would be judged.  And she would be alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...at the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone.  The past looks different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hatsue Miyamoto in the witness box. Graceful, erect, her beauty accessible, eager to cooperate.  Humble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopeful.  Is the word I would use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Nels seems slightly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Carl didn't say yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't say no.  That was Kabuo's point.  Given how Carl's mother felt, Carl was still willing to consider selling to us.  It was a good sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nels considers that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in the week that followed, the week before Carl's death... did your husband pursue him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Kabuo did not wish to beg, he respected Carl's right to reflect.  He was sure Carl would do the honorable thing. NELS (right back) And did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.  Only once.  Her eyes bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night of the 15th, Kabuo helped Carl at sea.  With his dead battery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nels raises his eyebrows.  To give the point its weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there, on the boat, they agreed.  $8400 for the seven acres, $800 down.  They shook on it.  Kabuo was so excited when he came home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nels lets that sit.  And sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when did you first learn. That Carl had drowned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slightest pause.  As if hesitant to confess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One o'clock, that afternoon, from a clerk at Petersen's. NELS (turning to Hooks) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
